awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ICARUS - Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative proposal to build an online, open-access, searchable, central repository for atmospheric chamber data in the United States called ICARUS (Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States).  Fundamental data obtained from chamber studies are routinely used as empirical inputs and constraints in atmospheric models. There are nine major U.S. research institutions participating in this project, including the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).  This sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data will synergistically facilitate atmospheric chemistry research in the U.S.

The specific objectives of the project are to (1) provide a searchable public index of the chamber experiments from each participating research group; (2) archive past chamber data from each participating group under their indexed chamber experiment; (3) standardize chamber data reporting formats; (4) provide a uniform template for chamber metadata; and (5) streamline future data submissions.  The data products included in ICARUS are: (A) gas phase data that describes the time-resolved profiles of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as gaseous hydrocarbons, oxidized VOCs, oxidants (OH, O3, NO3), NOx, SO2, and other data; (B) particle phase data that describes yields of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) as well as optical properties, composition (detailed molecular and bulk elemental ratios), and chemical functional groups; (C) supporting information such as relative humidity, temperature, and light flux; (D) the experimental notes required to understand the data (such as reaction timing, mixing procedures, seed particle addition, and so on); and (E) vapor and particulate wall deposition rates that are needed to correct chamber data.  At the end of the 3-year project, the database will be transitioned to the Data Stewardship Engineering Team at NCAR.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
The Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States (ICARUS) project created a user-friendly database management system for environmental chamber research conducted across the country.  The sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using U.S. atmospheric chamber experimental data provides a uniform platform for upload and storage of critical environmental chamber studies of atmospheric pollutants.  The database is available to a wide array of scientists interested in using environmmental chamber studies to enhance the scientific communities understanding of atmospheric processes including chemical mechanism development, improvement of and integration into local, regional, or global scale models, and evaluation of atmospheric chemical oxidation processes.  The final product (to date) includes input from 11 U.S. environmental chamber groups of 485 chamber experiments along with extensive chamber characterization data.  The platform will serve as a reservoir for many additional chamber experiments as scientists continue to upload historical, current, and future environmental chamber studies into the database. 

The development of this open-access database for atmospheric chemistry data sets improves the way that publically-funded results in this field are transferred and communicated to government entities, academic entities, and the general public.  Additionally, it is anticipated that ICARUS will be a useful tool for education and undergraduate research.  The results can be used to teach kinetics, modeling, curve fitting, atmospheric chemistry, or other topics--especially at schools/universities that do not have the extensive infrastructure for research.


Last Modified: 11/11/2022
Modified by: David Cocker Iii

The sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using U.S. atmospheric chamber experimental data provides a uniform platform for upload and storage of critical environmental chamber studies of atmospheric pollutants.  The database is available to a wide array of scientists interested in using environmmental chamber studies to enhance the scientific communities understanding of atmospheric processes including chemical mechanism development, improvement of and integration into local, regional, or global scale models, and evaluation of atmospheric chemical oxidation processes.  The final product (to date) includes input from 11 U.S. environmental chamber groups of 485 chamber experiments along with extensive chamber characterization data. The development of this open-access database for atmospheric chemistry data sets improves the way that publically-funded results in this field are transferred and communicated to government entities, academic entities, and the general public.
